title: 110_s553
content: The Act is titled the "Eightmile Wild and Scenic River Act" and designates the Eightmile River in Connecticut as a Wild and Scenic River. Congress finds that the Eightmile River in Connecticut has outstanding resource values including cultural landscapes, water quality, unique species, and watershed ecosystems. The Eightmile River Wild and Scenic Study Committee determined that the river's outstanding resource values depend on the integrity of its watershed. They took a watershed approach in studying and recommending management options for the river segments and the entire watershed. The Eightmile River Management Plan was prepared by the Eightmile River Wild and Scenic Study Committee to protect the river's values and manage its resources. The Committee recommended including the Eightmile River in the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System as part of the watershed management plan. The residents of towns near the Eightmile River watershed in Connecticut endorsed the Eightmile River Watershed Management Plan and sought designation of the river as part of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. The State of Connecticut also passed Public Act 05-18 to support the Management Plan and seek the river's designation. The Eightmile River in Connecticut is designated as part of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. The Management Plan was prepared by the Eightmile River Wild and Scenic Study Committee with assistance from the National Park Service. The Secretary of the Interior is referred to as the Secretary in this Act. The Eightmile River in Connecticut is designated as part of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. The river segments totaling approximately 25.3 miles are to be administered by the Secretary of the Interior. This includes the main stem and East Branch segments designated as scenic rivers. The Eightmile River in Connecticut is designated as part of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. The river segments totaling approximately 25.3 miles are to be administered by the Secretary of the Interior. Specific segments like Witch Meadow Road to the main stem, Harris Brook, Beaver Brook, and Falls Brook are designated as scenic rivers. The Secretary will manage the Eightmile River according to the Management Plan. The Secretary will coordinate management responsibilities for the Eightmile River with the Eightmile River Coordinating Committee as per the Management Plan. Cooperative agreements may be entered into with the State of Connecticut and the towns. The Eightmile River management will be coordinated with the Eightmile River Coordinating Committee as per the Management Plan. Cooperative agreements may involve the State of Connecticut, Salem, Lyme, and East Haddam towns, and local planning and environmental organizations. The agreements must align with the Management Plan and may include assistance from the United States. The Eightmile River will not be part of the National Park System. The Eightmile River will not be part of the National Park System and will not be subject to its regulations. Zoning ordinances in Salem, East Haddam, and Lyme, Connecticut will satisfy the standards of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. Federal acquisition of land by condemnation is prohibited under the Act. The Eightmile River will not be part of the National Park System and will not be subject to its regulations. Federal acquisition of land by condemnation is prohibited for the purpose of managing the Eightmile River as a component of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. Acquisition of land is limited to donation or with the consent of the owner, subject to additional criteria in the Management Plan. The Management Plan recognizes the importance of tributaries in protecting and enhancing the Eightmile River watershed. The covered tributaries include Beaver Brook, Big Brook, Burnhams Brook, Cedar Pond Brook, Cranberry Meadow Brook, Early Brook, Falls Brook, Fraser Brook, Harris Brook, Hedge Brook, Lake Hayward Brook, Malt House Brook, Muddy Brook, and Ransom Brook. The Eightmile River watershed management plan covers various tributaries including Muddy Brook, Ransom Brook, Rattlesnake Ledge Brook, Shingle Mill Brook, Strongs Brook, Tisdale Brook, Witch Meadow Brook, and other perennial streams. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of the Act.
